Summary

ID: 43940 Status: Submitted
Entered By: Lance Gaillou Comparison: Above Average
Entered: Event Type: N/A
Observed: City: Paris
Language: English Country: France
Reviewer: Lance Gaillou Subject: Gilles Piedalue
Reviewer Level: 3 Existing Level: 2
Reviewer Role: Other Subject Role: Other
Type: Evaluation
Strengths: I am happy to recommend Gilles Piedalue for advancement to Level 3

Rules and Policy Knowledge - This has historically been Gilles's strongest point and remains so today. Gilles's knowledge is excellent and extensive, on par or even better than a lot of L3s. In addition, Gilles has held several seminars about rules and is translating both documents and Judge Center questions, which helps make sure he is up to date and is a testimony to his ability to explain those rules to a wide audience.

Judge Assessment - This is Gilles's other very strong asset. His reviews are detailed and helpful and cover a variety of topics. Even though his reviewing has slowed down a bit this year, he has long been one of France's most proficient L2 reviewers.

Judge Program Philosophy, Policy/Penalty Philosophy - An active member of the community and a regular traveler to GPs, Gilles has participated in a lot of discussions, giving him a thorough view of the program. His interventions in policy discussions are often insightful, showing that he has not only a good knowledge of policies, but also a critical view on them, and good analytical skills to help move these discussions forward. He is also one of the most active posters on our judge forums, giving a good example of what productive policy discussions are - not a forceful answer dropping like a hammer, but a balanced exposition of points of view.

Teamwork and Diplomacy, Attitude and Maturity, Stress and Conflict Management - Gilles is a calm person, always preferring to let storms flow around him and to take thoughtful decisions, never being in a hurry. Because he accepts lots of external factors, including other people, as difficult or even impossible to change, his attitude is non-threatening, but rather that of a reassuring, almost zen-like figure. It occasionally happens that this systematic deliberateness frustrates people around him and leads to delays, but this remains a rare occasion. As long as Gilles doesn't have to handle a fire, he is fine.

Communication - Gilles has lots of experience writing, giving seminars, and leading teams. He is capable of expressing thoughts clearly in both French and Esperanto.

Investigation - though it's been some time since I last saw Gilles lead an investigation, he has done a few and reached correct conclusions every time. His analytical skills and experience as a player help him to understand players' motives and to decrypt a game state to detect any shadiness.
Areas for Improvement: Leadership - this is historically Gilles's weakest point. As an analytical, non-confrontational person, Gilles will often prefer thinking to diving into action, which in the past has caused delays (on the logistical side) and non-cohesive judge groups under his orders (on the judge management side). While Gilles has made a lot of progress, he still suffers from being somewhat "transparent." A big part of his judge work happens behind the scenes (leading translation projects, seminars) and Gilles isn't very comfortable with being under the spotlights, so he won't naturally try to take the leadership role. Often when talking with foreign judges, they won't be able to say much about Gilles, even if they had worked with him. I've given him recently a few tips on how to be remembered. Gilles should continue working on this even if he makes L3.

Self-Evaluation - Although Gilles has written a fair amount of self-evaluations, they weren't as effective as they could be. The reason is that Gilles analyzes his behavior, but doesn't make a good summary of his observations. An excellent self-review should give a mix of short-term and long-term goals, with clear statements and focus on 2-3 goals rather than on 10 (which is a good way of achieving none). Gilles's first version of the L3 checklist self-evaluation was quite scattered, with as many as 10 Qualities both in Strengths and Areas for improvement. After talking with him, he made a second version which was much better. If Gilles continues to write such reviews, but spontaneously rather than when prompted, I will consider this a Strength.
Comments: Mentorship - this is an area where I have very little information. Though Gilles will often talk about some candidate, he hasn't certified many judges, especially in his own region where Arthur Panetier and Gauvain Pepin are the primary recruiters.

Gilles, it's been quite a few years since you started judging, and what a path this has been! Even though you've been hinting at L3 for a couple years now and decided at first that it wasn't for you, I think you've finally reached the point where you are more of an L3 than L2. Your quiet and non-assertive nature has made this progression a bit slower than it could have been, but this deliberate pace has enabled you to build a solid reputation as translations leader and generally very knowledgeable judge, having traveled to many GPs and built a network of contacts.
